misconceptions.task: Reading numeric grade input
misconceptions.name: Reads point coordinates and hard-codes grade instead of reading grade input
misconceptions.description: The program asks the user for two points (x1, y1, x2, y2) and then hard-codes `int grade = 85` instead of reading a single numeric grade from the user as required. The grade used in the conditional logic is not connected to any user input.
misconceptions.student_belief: I can read in some input (like x1, y1, x2, y2) to use the Scanner, and then just assign `grade = 85` directly in the code for my grade check instead of reading the grade from the user.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For this problem, the program should prompt the user to enter a single numeric grade between 0 and 100 and store that value in a variable (e.g., with `nextInt()` or `nextDouble()`). That input variable should then be used in the conditional logic to determine and print the letter grade; it should not be hard-coded.
symptoms: Program prompts for coordinates instead of a numeric grade.
No prompt or input for a grade value.
The `grade` variable is assigned a constant value `85` rather than being read from the keyboard.
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely confusion between this question and a previous 'distance between points' problem, combined with a misunderstanding that using a fixed test value in the final code is acceptable instead of reading the required input from the user.
misconceptions.remediation_hint:
Replace the coordinate prompts and inputs with a single prompt for the numeric grade (0–100), e.g., `System.out.print("Enter grade: "); int grade = input.nextInt();`. Then use that `grade` variable in your `if` / `else if` / `else` structure to choose the correct letter grade.

Overall feedback: You know how to use Scanner and mathematical functions, but you need to focus more on matching the problem specification exactly. For this question, that means reading one grade value, checking the specified ranges, and printing the corresponding letter, not reusing code from another problem.
related_concepts: Using variables vs hard-coded test values
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The program clearly implements a distance-between-points input pattern and never reads a grade from the user; `grade` is explicitly hard-coded to 85.

evidence.note: Prompts and reads coordinates instead of a single numeric grade.

evidence.snippet: int grade = 85;
evidence.note: Grade is hard-coded rather than read from the keyboard.

misconceptions.task: Mapping each range to correct letter output
misconceptions.name: Does not map numeric grade ranges to letter grades
misconceptions.description: The program never computes or prints a letter grade. The only `if` condition checks whether a hard-coded grade (85) lies in one range, and both the `if` and `else` branches print the distance between two points instead of a letter grade.
misconceptions.student_belief: As long as I have an `if` statement involving the grade, the problem is addressed, even if I don’t actually print a letter grade or handle all the specified ranges.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program must use the numeric grade to select exactly one of the letter grades A, B, C, D, or F based on the specified ranges, and then print that letter (e.g., `Letter grade: B`). This requires a full chain of conditions (A, B, C, D) with a final `else` for F, all producing letter outputs.
symptoms: No `System.out` call that prints a letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F).
Only one condition is checked (80–90 range), and both branches output the same distance text.
Grade ranges for A, C, D, and F are not handled at all.
misconceptions.root_cause: The student likely focused on reusing an earlier distance-calculation program and did not translate the problem requirements (mapping numerical intervals to letter outputs) into a full conditional structure.
misconceptions.remediation_hint:
Remove the distance-related output from this question. After correctly reading the numeric grade, write an `if` / `else if` chain:
- `if (grade >= 90 && grade <= 100) System.out.println("Letter grade: A");`
- `else if (grade >= 80) System.out.println("Letter grade: B");`
- `else if (grade >= 70) ...` and so on, with a final `else` for `F`. Make sure each branch prints the correct letter.

Also add the exact text format from the example, e.g., `System.out.println("Letter grade: B");`.
related_concepts: Mapping numeric values to categorical outputs
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: There is no code that prints any letter grade, and the only conditional branches both print the distance string; none of the defined grade ranges are mapped to letters.

evidence.note: Conditional checks a single numeric range and both branches print the distance; no letter grade output anywhere.

misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for A and B
misconceptions.name: Using & instead of && for logical conjunction in condition
misconceptions.description: The condition `grade >= 80 & grade < 90` uses the single `&` operator instead of the more appropriate short-circuit logical AND operator `&&` in a boolean expression.
misconceptions.student_belief: The `&` operator is interchangeable with `&&` for combining boolean conditions in `if` statements.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: In Java, `&&` is the standard logical AND for conditions and short-circuits (it skips evaluating the right-hand side if the left is false). The single `&` is primarily a bitwise AND operator and, when used on booleans, evaluates both sides every time. For clarity and conventional style, `&&` should be used for combining boolean test conditions.
symptoms: Boolean condition uses `&` instead of `&&` between relational tests.
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely confusion from other languages or from seeing `&` used with integers, leading to the belief that it is the normal logical AND operator in all contexts.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Replace `&` with `&&` in boolean expressions that combine logical tests, e.g., change `if (grade >= 80 & grade < 90)` to `if (grade >= 80 && grade < 90)`. Review the difference between bitwise and logical operators in Java.
related_concepts: Logical vs bitwise operators in Java
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: While `&` works with booleans, beginners are almost always expected to use `&&` in conditions; its use here suggests a misunderstanding of the distinction.

evidence.snippet: if (grade >= 80 & grade < 90) {
evidence.note: Single `&` is used in a boolean condition where `&&` would be the conventional logical operator.

misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for A and B
misconceptions.name: Misuse of Bitwise AND (`&`) for Logical AND (`&&`)
misconceptions.description: The student used the bitwise AND operator (`&`) to combine boolean expressions within the conditional statement, instead of the standard logical AND operator (`&&`). Although `&` may work for boolean operands, `&&` is preferred because it uses short-circuit evaluation.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes that `&` and `&&` are interchangeable symbols for logical 'AND', or is unaware of short-circuiting.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: `&&` is the logical AND operator in Java used for conditional checks, which performs short-circuit evaluation. `&` is primarily for bitwise operations.
symptoms: Non-short-circuiting operator used in conditional logic.
misconceptions.root_cause: Confusion between Java's bitwise and logical operators.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Use `&&` (Logical AND) and `||` (Logical OR) when combining boolean conditions in 'if' statements to ensure proper short-circuiting and efficiency.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: It is a clear use of `&` where `&&` is convention and best practice.

evidence.snippet: if (grade >= 80 & grade < 90) {
evidence.note: The bitwise AND operator (`&`) is used instead of the logical AND operator (`&&`).

misconceptions.task: Reading numeric grade input
misconceptions.name: Implementing a different problem and hard-coding the grade
misconceptions.description:
The program is essentially a distance-between-points calculator, not a grade-to-letter converter. It reads four doubles (x1, y1, x2, y2), computes a distance, and prints that distance in both branches of an if/else. The only connection to the grade problem is a hard-coded int grade = 85 used only in the condition. This suggests the student is not mapping the written specification (read a numeric grade and output a letter) into the structure of their code.

Rubric scoring for this submission:
- Reading numeric grade input: 0/1 — The program never reads a grade; it only reads coordinates.
- Correct Boolean ranges for A and B: 0/1 — There is a single condition for the B range that is not connected to any letter-grade output, and A is not handled.
- Correct Boolean ranges for C and D: 0/1 — No conditions for C or D are present.
- Correct handling of F (default/else): 0/1 — No else or default case for F; the else branch still prints the distance, not an F.
- Mapping each range to correct letter output: 0/1 — The output is always the numeric distance; no letter grades (A–F) are ever printed.
misconceptions.student_belief: I can reuse my distance-between-points code and just add a grade variable/condition, and that will satisfy the grade-calculator problem, even if I keep printing the distance.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For this task, the program should (1) read a single numeric grade (0–100) from the user, and (2) use conditional statements to map that grade to a letter A–F, printing only the letter grade as the main result (possibly with a label). Any unrelated calculations, like distances between points, should be removed.
symptoms: Program prompts for coordinates (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of a single grade.
Program computes and prints a distance value, not a letter grade.
Grade is hard-coded as int grade = 85 and never read from input.
Output format does not match the required 'Letter grade: X' style.
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely copy-pasting from an earlier exercise about distances and then superficially adding an if-statement based on a grade variable, without fully rethinking the program structure according to the new specification.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Start from the problem statement, not from old code. Delete the distance-related prompts, variables, and calculations. Write a fresh program that: (1) asks the user to 'Enter grade: ', (2) reads a single int or double grade from the Scanner, and (3) uses if/else-if/else to check which range (A, B, C, D, F) the grade falls into, and prints 'Letter grade: X'. After you have the correct behavior, you can think about formatting or minor improvements.
related_concepts: Using Scanner to read user input
Designing if/else chains to cover all cases
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire structure of the program (inputs, computation, and outputs) matches a distance problem, not the described grade problem, and the grade is hard-coded and unused in the output.

evidence.note: Reads four doubles for coordinates and computes a distance, which is unrelated to reading a numeric grade as required.

evidence.snippet: int grade = 85;
evidence.note: The grade is hard-coded instead of being read from the user.
Regardless of the grade, the program prints the numeric distance, never a letter grade.

misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for A and B
misconceptions.name: Using bitwise & instead of logical && in conditional expressions
misconceptions.description: The condition for the B range uses the single ampersand operator (&) between two boolean expressions instead of the logical AND operator (&&). While this happens to work similarly for this specific code, it indicates confusion between bitwise and logical operators for booleans.
misconceptions.student_belief: I can use & between two boolean comparisons in an if-statement and it is the normal way to write logical AND.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: In Java, && is the logical AND operator used in conditional expressions; it also short-circuits (skips evaluating the right-hand side if the left is false). The single & on boolean operands is a non-short-circuit AND and is rarely what you want for normal if conditions. For integer bit manipulation, & is used as a bitwise AND.
symptoms: Condition is written as grade >= 80 & grade < 90 instead of grade >= 80 && grade < 90.
misconceptions.root_cause: Mixing up the boolean logical AND (&&) with the bitwise AND (&), possibly due to exposure to other languages or not having seen short-circuit behavior explained clearly.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Change the condition to use &&: if (grade >= 80 && grade < 90). Review the difference between && and & in Java, and always default to && when combining boolean conditions in if/while statements.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The single & appears in exactly the place where && is standard; there is no apparent need for bitwise or non-short-circuit behavior here.

evidence.snippet: if (grade >= 80 & grade < 90) {
evidence.note: Uses & instead of && between two boolean comparisons.

misconceptions.task: Mapping each range to correct letter output
misconceptions.name: Using if/else without changing program behavior or mapping to letters
misconceptions.description: Both the if and else branches print exactly the same distance message, and neither branch outputs a letter grade. The grade variable only affects which branch is taken, but since the branches are identical, the condition has no observable effect. This suggests a misunderstanding of the purpose of if/else in implementing distinct behaviors (like different letter outputs).
misconceptions.student_belief: As long as I have an if-statement that mentions the grade, I have 'used' conditionals for the grade problem, even if both branches do the same thing and don't output a letter.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: If/else exists to choose between different actions. For a grade calculator, each range (A, B, C, D, F) should correspond to a branch that produces a different letter output. The body of each branch should clearly reflect which case it is handling, typically by printing 'Letter grade: A' (or B, etc.) rather than repeating the same message.
symptoms: if and else branches contain identical print statements.
Neither branch prints any letter grade; both only print the distance.
The grade variable is only used in the condition and not in the output.
misconceptions.root_cause: Focusing on satisfying the apparent requirement 'use an if statement with grade' rather than ensuring that each branch produces the correct distinct outcome required by the specification.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Replace the repeated distance-printing lines with separate outputs for each grade range. For example: if (grade >= 90) { System.out.println("Letter grade: A"); } else if (grade >= 80) { System.out.println("Letter grade: B"); } ... else { System.out.println("Letter grade: F"); }. Make sure each branch outputs a different letter and that no unrelated distance printing remains.
related_concepts: Exhaustive case coverage with else-if chains
Mapping numeric ranges to categorical outputs
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The identical bodies of the if and else branches and the absence of any letter-grade output strongly indicate misuse or incomplete understanding of conditionals for this task.

evidence.note: Both branches of the conditional output the same distance message and never output a letter grade.

misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe they are solving a distance calculation problem, as evidenced by the class name, variable names (x1, y1, x2, y2), and mathematical formula used.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires a grade calculator that reads a single numeric grade and outputs a letter grade. The program must check ranges (90-100 to A, 80-89 to B, etc.) and output the appropriate letter.
symptoms: Class is named Q3DistanceBetweenPoints instead of something like GradeCalculator
Code reads four values (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of one grade
Uses distance formula: Math.sqrt(Math.pow(x2-x1, 2) + Math.pow(y2-y1, 2))
Outputs distance instead of letter grade
No grade range checking logic
misconceptions.root_cause: Student may have copied code from a previous assignment or worked on the wrong problem. Suggests they didn't carefully read the problem specification or mixed up different assignments.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Start over with the correct problem. Read one grade value, use if-else statements to check which range it falls into (90+ for A, 80-89 for B, etc.), and print the corresponding letter grade.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Certain. The code is unambiguously solving a different problem. The structure, variable names, class name, and algorithm all point to a distance calculator, not a grade calculator.

evidence.note: Entire program is structured for calculating distance between two points using the Pythagorean theorem, not for reading and converting a grade to a letter.

misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for A and B
misconceptions.name: Bitwise AND operator used instead of logical AND
misconceptions.description: The student uses the bitwise AND operator & instead of the logical AND operator && in a conditional expression.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student may believe that & and && are interchangeable or equivalent for combining boolean conditions.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: Use && (logical AND) for boolean conditions in if statements. The & operator is bitwise AND and evaluates both sides even when the short-circuit evaluation of && would be more efficient. For booleans, always use && or ||.
symptoms: Use of single ampersand & in conditional: if (grade >= 80 & grade < 90)
Semantically incorrect operator choice for boolean logic
misconceptions.root_cause: Confusion between bitwise operators (used for integer operations) and logical operators (used for boolean operations). The student may not understand that & is a bitwise operator.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Replace the single & with double &&: if (grade >= 80 && grade < 90) for logical AND operations on booleans.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Clear syntax issue with & vs &&. While functionally this may work due to implicit conversions, it is semantically incorrect. High confidence this reveals underlying confusion about operator types.

evidence.snippet: if (grade >= 80 & grade < 90) {
evidence.note: Single ampersand & used instead of logical AND && for boolean condition combining
